definition[0]: when you decide not to have something valuable, in order to get something that is more important
example[0]: The minister stressed the need for economic sacrifice.
example[1]: The workforce were willing to make sacrifices in order to preserve jobs.
example[2]: She brought three children up single-handedly, often at great personal sacrifice.
definition[1]: the act of offering something to a god, especially in the past, by killing an animal or person in a religious ceremony
example[3]: They made sacrifices to ensure a good harvest.
definition[2]: an animal, person, or object offered to a god in sacrifice
example[4]: a human sacrifice  (=a person killed as a sacrifice)
example[5]: In those days, an animal was offered as a sacrifice to God.
definition[3]: to willingly stop having something you want or doing something you like in order to get something more important
example[6]: A Labour government chose to sacrifice defence for welfare.
example[7]: He sacrificed a promising career to look after his kids.
example[8]: mothers who sacrifice themselves for their children
explanation[0]: In everyday English, people often say give up rather than sacrifice:
example[9]: He gave up a promising career to look after his kids.
definition[4]: to kill an animal or person and offer them to a god in a religious ceremony
definition[5]: something valuable that you decide not to have, in order to get something that is more important
example[10]: The directors are willing to make certain sacrifices to make the company financially viable.
example[11]: Lawyers who choose to work in smaller firms often make a substantial economic sacrifice.
example[12]: The self-employed sacrifice security for the power to regulate their own careers.
example[13]: In order to stay competitive, the company has had to sacrifice profit margins.
